G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and applicable jurisdictional provisions governing the District Court Department, this Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action because the amount in controversy falls within the monetary jurisdiction of the Lynn District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 2 because the cause of action arose in Lynn, Essex County, Massachusetts, where the Premises are located and where Plaintiff’s injuries occurred.

Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a continuing non-delegable duty as landlord to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas of the Premises, including fire safety systems and smoke detectors, in a reasonably safe and code-compliant condition.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).support_reasoning: Young v. Garwacki does recognize a landlord’s general tort duty to exercise reasonable care as to the safety of premises, including areas demised to the tenant, and extends that duty to tenants’ guests. However, it does not frame this duty as “non‑delegable,” nor does it specifically address or single out fire safety systems or smoke detectors, or impose a distinct, continuing duty to maintain common areas in a code‑compliant condition. The case is about general negligence liability for defective premises (a porch railing), not a specialized, non‑delegable duty regarding building code compliance or fire protection systems in common areas.
Young v. Garwacki, 380 Mass. 162 (1980).relevant_excerpt: “Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. … Thus, at least to the extent required by the relevant housing and building codes, a landlord may be liable to his tenant for failing to maintain areas not under the landlord’s control.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a continuing non-delegable duty as landlord to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas of the Premises, including fire safety systems and smoke detectors, in a reasonably safe and code-compliant condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurring opinion discussing the abolition of the invitee/licensee distinction and questioning the continued separate treatment of trespassers. It does not address landlord-tenant law, common areas, or any non-delegable duty of a landlord to maintain fire safety systems or smoke detectors. Therefore, it does not support the specific proposition about a landlord’s continuing non-delegable duty to maintain common areas and safety systems in a code-compliant condition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that ‘trespassers’ stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

G.L. c. 148, \u00a7\u00a7 26E, 26F, 26F\.proposition: At all relevant times, Massachusetts law required smoke detectors in residential buildings and imposed obligations on owners and managers to maintain and keep such equipment in working order.

527 CMR 1.00 et seq..proposition: At all relevant times, Massachusetts law required smoke detectors in residential buildings and imposed obligations on owners and managers to maintain and keep such equipment in working order.

Massachusetts State Building Code, 780 C.proposition: At all relevant times, Massachusetts law required smoke detectors in residential buildings and imposed obligations on owners and managers to maintain and keep such equipment in working order.

Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).proposition: Defendant’s failure to act, despite repeated notice, created an unreasonable risk of physical harm to Plaintiff and other tenants and constituted a breach of Defendant’s duty of reasonable care.
Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).support_reasoning: The decision squarely rejects the idea that these defendants’ failure to act created an unreasonable risk of physical harm or breached any duty of reasonable care. The court holds there was no common‑law or statutory duty on the director, assistant director, or other officers to provide or replace roof railings, and thus no negligence in failing to do so despite their safety responsibilities. It further concludes that merely retaining a general right to stop work or direct correction of safety issues is insufficient control to create liability for the independent contractor’s safety lapses.
Lyon v. Morphew, 424 Mass. 828 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “From the evidence viewed in a light most favorable to the plaintiff, it could be inferred that they played a role in determining whether the hospital should replace the railing or install an alternative safety device; however, they had no common law or statutory duty to do either. … Because we have determined that there was no duty to provide a safety railing on the roof of the ‘B’ building, we conclude that removing the railing thought to be corroded did not constitute negligence.”

Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661 (1945.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act, despite repeated notice, created an unreasonable risk of physical harm to Plaintiff and other tenants and constituted a breach of Defendant’s duty of reasonable care.
Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661 (1945.support_reasoning: The case involves an employee’s wrongful death claim against his employer, not a landlord-tenant situation, and the alleged negligence was a regulatory violation (failure to provide roof staging), not failure to act after repeated notice. More importantly, the court holds that even assuming a duty and a violation, there was insufficient evidence of causation, and it orders judgment for the defendant. Thus, the opinion does not support the proposition that defendant’s failure to act after notice created an unreasonable risk and constituted a breach of duty; it instead emphasizes that negligence (including regulatory violations) must be shown to be a contributing cause of the injury.
Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661 (1945.relevant_excerpt: “To recover, the plaintiff was required to prove negligence on the part of the defendant that contributed to cause the death of her intestate. The plaintiff urges that this requirement has been met because the failure of the defendant to set up any staging on the roof where the intestate was working constituted a violation of Rule 6… [N]evertheless we are of opinion that the case should not have been submitted to the jury… The evidence would not warrant a finding that the violation of Rule 6, if there was one, bore any causal relation to the death of the intestate.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a claim of negligence requires proof of duty, breach, causation, and damages.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the elements a plaintiff must prove to prevail on a negligence claim in Massachusetts: duty, breach, causation, and damages. It cites a tort treatise for this formulation and uses it as the governing framework for analyzing the negligence claim in the case, so it directly supports the proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005)."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a claim of negligence requires proof of duty, breach, causation, and damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The court explicitly describes what the plaintiffs must prove to prevail on their negligence claims, listing breach of duty, actual loss (damages), and causation as essential elements and citing standard tort authorities. Although it does not separately use the word “duty” in the initial clause, it speaks in terms of “breach of the duty to use reasonable care,” which presupposes the existence of a duty, and clearly identifies causation and damages as required elements, consistent with the proposition.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: As owner and/or manager of the Premises, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas, including fire safety and detection equipment, in a condition that was reasonably safe for lawful occupants and invitees.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The opinion does affirm that an owner or possessor of land owes lawful entrants a duty of reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition, but it does not address common areas of multi-unit premises or fire safety/detection equipment. The case concerns a backyard trampoline–pool setup and the open-and-obvious danger doctrine, not building fire safety systems or specific obligations regarding common areas. Therefore it is too general and contextually inapposite to serve as authority for the specific duty regarding common areas and fire safety equipment stated in the proposition.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’” (citing Mounsey v. Ellard).

Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.raw_text: Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mass. 362, 365 (1980)
Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care of a reasonable landlord and property manager under like circumstances and violated the duty of reasonable care owed under Massachusetts law.
Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion is a products liability/negligent design case against an automobile manufacturer, not a premises liability case involving a landlord or property manager. It does not discuss the standard of care for landlords, duties owed by landlords to tenants or entrants, or Massachusetts landlord premises liability law. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed proposition about a reasonable landlord’s duty of care.
Griffin v. General Motors Corp., 380 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff’s automobile, manufactured by the defendant, caught fire while she was driving it, and she was severely burned. On a theory of negligent design, a jury has awarded her $1,000,000 in damages… The plaintiff’s experts testified that the negligent design of the hood and fresh air system permitted fumes from a gasoline leak in the engine compartment to enter the passenger compartment…

Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.raw_text: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc., 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.proposition: Violations of statutes and regulations designed to protect occupants of residential buildings from fire and smoke hazards, including G.L. c. 148 and applicable fire and building codes, constitute evidence of negligence and support a finding of breach.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.support_reasoning: The case does discuss the effect of violating a statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69) and reiterates the general Massachusetts rule that statutory violations are only “some evidence” of negligence and do not constitute negligence per se. However, it concerns liquor liability, not fire or building safety statutes, and it emphasizes that a statutory violation does not by itself establish a breach. It therefore does not specifically address, or provide authority for, the proposition about fire and smoke hazard statutes and building codes, and to the extent it is relevant, it undercuts any claim that such violations automatically support a finding of breach.
Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, In.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.raw_text: MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp., 394 Mass. 131, 139–40 (1985)
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.proposition: Violations of statutes and regulations designed to protect occupants of residential buildings from fire and smoke hazards, including G.L. c. 148 and applicable fire and building codes, constitute evidence of negligence and support a finding of breach.
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns product liability and the duty of a prescription drug manufacturer to warn consumers, not premises liability or building/fire safety. Its brief discussion of regulatory violations as evidence of negligence is limited to FDA labeling regulations and failure-to-warn standards, not to G.L. c. 148 or fire and building codes protecting residential occupants. Therefore, it does not establish that violations of fire and building safety statutes or regulations constitute evidence of negligence in the residential context.
MacDonald v. Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp.,.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, compliance with FDA requirements, though admissible to demonstrate lack of negligence, is not conclusive on this issue, just as violation of FDA requirements is evidence, but not conclusive evidence, of negligence. See Deignan v. Lubarsky, 318 Mass. 661, 664 (1945).”

Fennell v. W. R. Grace & Co., 41 Mass. A.raw_text: Fennell v. W. R. Grace & Co., 41 Mass. App. Ct. 206, 209–10 (1996)
Fennell v. W. R. Grace & Co., 41 Mass. A.proposition: Defendant’s negligence substantially increased the risk that Plaintiff would be exposed to dangerous levels of smoke and that she would sustain smoke inhalation injuries and related harm.
Fennell v. W. R. Grace & Co., 41 Mass. A.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns the proper use and limits of the court’s summary contempt power in response to a defendant’s alleged lying about misidentification. It does not involve negligence, increased risk, smoke exposure, or smoke inhalation injuries, nor does it address causation principles related to increased risk of harm. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about a defendant’s negligence substantially increasing the risk of smoke-related injuries.
Fennell v. W. R. Grace & Co., 41 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: “However understandable the judge’s motive, this was not a proper occasion for an exercise of the summary contempt power which by long tradition is conceived narrowly and used with great restraint… The present case is far distant from that model and not amenable to rule 43. How can it be said that summary punishment was necessary to maintain order in the courtroom: there was no threat of disorder.”

Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth., 443.raw_text: Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth., 443 Mass. 697, 701–02 (2005)
Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth., 443.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered and continues to suffer pain and suffering, emotional distress, anxiety, and loss of enjoyment of life resulting from the incident and her injuries.
Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth., 443.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether plaintiffs may recover damages for negligent infliction of emotional distress resulting from home invasions and discusses the legal requirements for such recovery. It does not state or analyze that a particular plaintiff "has suffered and continues to suffer" pain and suffering, emotional distress, anxiety, or loss of enjoyment of life in the way a damages allegation is typically pled in a complaint. While it acknowledges emotional distress and related symptoms, it does not serve as authority for the specific proposition about ongoing individual injuries and loss of enjoyment of life; rather, it addresses the legal standard for emotional distress claims and the sufficiency of evidence.
Rodriguez v. Cambridge Hous. Auth., 443.relevant_excerpt: “As a consequence of this second attack and the resulting trauma, both Carmen and Samuel were admitted to Cambridge Hospital for seventeen days.… Carmen was diagnosed as suffering from the symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder and major depression. Samuel exhibited the symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder, nightmares, and suicidal thoughts that necessitated observation every five minutes.… We conclude that Samuel was entitled to recover damages for negligent infliction of emotional distress for the May 18 home invasion.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is also entitled to statutory interest on any judgment pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, and costs as provided by law.

Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declarat.raw_text: Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights
Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declarat.proposition: Pursuant to Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.

Mass. R. Civ. P. 38.proposition: Pursuant to Article 15 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights and Mass. R. Civ. P. 38, Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable.
